body: ðŸ‘ðŸ¼ for distinguishing syntactic errors and content errors. `serde_json::Error` has a `classify()` method that allows to check what failed exactly.

> This is not documented correctly: https://docs.rs/axum/latest/axum/struct.Json.html In this documentation both of them would result in 400 Bad Request

Good catch. Thats easy to fix!

> 422 Unprocessable Entity seems to be part of an HTTP extension intended for WebDAV. Is it appropriate to use this in a non-WebDAV server?

Yeah its common. I know that Ruby on Rails uses it for a bunch of default things. MDN also doesn't mention thats its special https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/422.

> The description of 422 Unprocessable Entity https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4918#section-11.2 says that this should be used for syntactically correct, but semantically wrong requests. I also get that with a syntactically wrong JSON like }

Yeah we should fix that. Shouldn't be hard using what jplatte is hinting at.

@kamulos Are you up for making a PR for this?

issue.title: Make status codes for `JsonRejection` more precise

repository.name: axum

body: I made a PR for it https://github.com/tokio-rs/axum/pull/868.

@davidpdrsn the docs are still wrong though, we still have

> If the request body cannot be parsed, or it does not contain the `Content-Type: application/json` header, it will reject the request and return a `400 Bad Request` response.

issue.title: Fix out of date docs for `Json`

repository.name: axum

issue.title: Wrong query string should yield 400, not 422

repository.name: axum
repository.description: Ergonomic and modular web framework built with Tokio, Tower, and Hyper

issue.body:
## Bug Report

### Version

axum v0.5.0-rc.2

### Platform

Darwin mbp16.local 21.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 21.6.0: Wed Aug 10 14:28:23 PDT 2022; root:xnu-8020.141.5~2/RELEASE_ARM64_T6000 arm64

### Description

The Query extractor, if unable to serialize results, yields 422 Unprocessable entity.

However, I expect it should return 400, Bad Request.

422 is appropriate when the body is well-formed, but semantically incorrect, and 422 is commonly returned from other frameworks for JSON deserialization errors.

However, I have never seen a bad query string yield 422; typically a bad query string would yield 400 ("The client should not repeat this request without modification.")

Ultimately my suggestion is to keep current behavior for Body extractors such as Json, but return 400 for failed Query extractor.

**references:**

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/422
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/400

**Some prior discussion on 422**
https://github.com/tokio-rs/axum/issues/865
